Comment: Taxation...is...theft?   This is a line of thinking that kills me, because it implies someone has done absolutely zero interrogation into what they actually bring to the table, on a social scale. Someone considering taxes "theft" must never have walked on a sidewalk or enjoyed the (relative, dubious) safety offered by police and emergency services. They must have never gone to a public school or had some vital function in their life performed by someone who did. They must be growing their own food, since subsidies are tax-funded. They must have no interest in a national defense of *any* kind, smaller or otherwise.   Someone who considers taxes theft fails to understand that, in isolation, we are quite literally dead. Taxes are not "theft," they are a contribution to the general welfare for the purpose of creating a rising tide that'll lift all the boats.   Even these rich folks whose money you feel so obliged to protect (another temporarily embarrassed billionaire, I guess) are *nothing* without the droves of employees actually conducting the work and creating value, and those employees come to work on paved roads and probably spent at least a little time in public school.   Theft is *not* paying your taxes and leaving hungry children all over the country without school lunch so Elon Musk can drill holes in monkey skulls to stick his toxic tech in there.   What is "unjust" is that we allow civics education to regress this far.
Author: Angstrom_Wither

Comment: Let‚Äôs use fake numbers.   100,000 people making 50k ($5million total dollars) gets taxed 20% (10,000 each) = 1 million for the government. Someone making 5 million gets taxed 10% (500,000) = 500,000 for the government.  Why is the majority of the tax burden on the group of people that make barely enough to survive? One person makes the same amount of money 100,000 people and for some reason that gives them a pass on paying the same percentage of in taxes? And these are baby numbers.  Taking 20% of someone making 50k has a much higher quality of life impact than taking 20% of someone who makes 5 million.  Why are you advocating that rich people pay less? Every dollar a rich person makes is worth more than a dollar a middle class person makes because of this.
Author: Indurum

Comment: Couple things: That single individual is contributing 50% of what 100k people are. That‚Äôs HUGELY beneficially for society. The absolute value of taxes paid is highly relevant, to discount that is silly. Now, I‚Äôm not saying that person should be taxed less but not significantly more either. I think we want a society where wealth generation is incentivized, and extremely high taxation is likely to hurt that incentive. You‚Äôre killing the golden goose. Regarding your specific example, I think those people making 50k should be taxed no more than 10%, but I wouldn‚Äôt be comfortable taxing the 5 million dollar person more than 20%.
